resp:
<think>
Alright, I'm trying to figure out whether the claim "john brill be the only player on the list who play 2 position" is TRUE or FALSE based on the provided table. Let's break this down step by step.

First, I need to understand what the claim is saying. It states that John Brill is the only player in the list who plays two positions. So, I should check each player's position and see if anyone else besides John Brill has multiple positions listed.

Looking at the table, each row represents a different player with various details. The "position" column is where the relevant information will be found. Let me go through each player one by one to see their positions.

Starting from pick 43, Stephane Morin plays center. That's just one position. Next, Jason Zent is a left wing—again, only one position. Rob Zamuner is also a left wing. Moving on, Jason Cirone is a centre, another single position. Scott Pellerin is a left wing, same as before.

Bob Kellogg is listed as defence, which is singular. Louie DeBrusk plays left wing. Veli-Pekka Kautonen is a defence. Pierre Sevigny is a left wing. Blair Atcheynum plays right wing. Nicklas Lidstrom is defence. John Tanner is a goaltender, so that's one position.

Denny Felsner is a left wing. Scott Thomas is a right wing. Wes Walz is centre. Now we come to John Brill at pick 58. His position is listed as "left / right wing." That clearly indicates he can play two positions: left and right wing. So, John Brill does have two positions.

Continuing down the list to check if anyone else has multiple positions. Jim Mathieson is defence. Murray Garbutt is centre. Jason Woolley is defence. Kris Draper is also defence. Corey Lyons plays right wing. 

Going through all 20 players (picks 43-62), only John Brill's position entry includes a slash, indicating he has two positions: left and right wing. All other players have single positions listed without any indication of multiple roles.

Therefore, the claim that John Brill is the only player on the list who plays two positions holds true based on the information in the table.
</think>
